Award.AwardTitle: NeTS JUNO: Collaborative Research: ACTION: Applications Coordinating with Transport, IP, and Optical Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Today's Internet is significantly over-provisioned for a number of reasons, e.g., to absorb traffic bursts, to handle the extra (rerouted) load when failures occur, and for long-term traffic growth without frequent upgrades in the field. This overprovisioning adds significant capital costs to the Internet.

The ACTION project enables adaptation of the Internet to changing needs and demands by dynamically adjusting its "optical highway" capacities based on network resource utilization. The project name ACTION stands for "Applications Coordinate through Transport Interfaces with Optical Networks," implying that the capacity of the Internet optical highways is a time-adjustable commodity, which can be intelligently controlled by the applications via specially designed interfaces. For example, part of the optical spectrum can be freed on highways with low traffic volume and either reassigned to other highways where needed or switched off to conserve energy. Such flexible highways are achieved by combining WDM (Wavelength Division Multiplexing) Flexible Grid technology in the metro-core with DSCM (Digital Subcarrier Multiplexing) technology in the campus/access. The ACTION research activities will culminate in a final demonstration on the Japan Gigabit Network-extreme (JGN-X) test-bed.

The ACTION project will actively engage undergraduate students in Senior Thesis and Design Projects, recruit women and under-represented minorities by leveraging the UVA Center for Diversity in Engineering and the UTDallas long-standing relationship with CONACYT (National Council for Science and Technology of Mexico). Findings, documents, links to publications and software will be disseminated through a wiki-based Web site. All instructional materials developed will be made available at TeachEngineering.com.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

NSF CNS-1405171: NeTS JUNO: Collaborative Research: ACTION: Applications Coordinating with Transport, IP, and Optical Networks

In 2014, energy consumption of datacenters, and more broadly, the Information and Communication Technology (ICT) sector, was growing rapidly. This was of major concern, especially in Japan because of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster (this project was a joint US/Japan collaboration). A second concern was that Internet traffic volume was growing exponentially, but that networks were being overprovisioned and hence underutilized. A Google paper reported that wide-area network links are typically utilized only at 30-40% levels.

On the technology side, rapid improvements are being made to enhance flexibility of optical multiplexing and switching components. Optical networks underlie the IP-routed networks of the Internet. In other words, IP routers, which act in a manner similar to post offices, forward packets arriving on one communication link to another, toward their destinations. However two IP routers, especially in core and metro networks, are seldom directly connected to each other via an optical communication link. Instead, an optical circuit is provisioned through an underlying network consisting of add/drop multiplexers and optical crossconnects to interconnect two IP routers. IP routers, use electronics, not optics, and consequently consume more power. On the other hand, optical circuit switches switch lightwaves from one link to another using mirrors and mechanical methods (e.g., MicroElectroMechanical Systems, or MEMS). Therefore, optical circuit switches consume a lot less power than electronic packet switches (IP routers). New optical switching technologies, beyond MEMS, have significantly decreased circuit reconfiguration times, allowing for the optical-network layer to offer greater flexibility.

The objective of this NSF project was to answer the question of whether we can leverage these new optical switching technologies across campus, access, datacenter, metro and core (nationwide-backbone) networks to address this dual problem of energy consumption and poor efficiency in the usage of network bandwidth. Our proposed approach was to redesign applications if needed, and improve the various protocol layers involved in networking, to achieve our objective.

The key outcomes of this project related to intellectual merit criteria are as follows: (i) an overall  Applications Coordinating with Transport, IP, and Optical Networks (ACTION) architecture for access, metro, core and datacenter networks; (ii) a hybrid architecture called Optical Switch in the Middle (OSM) for datacenter networks, which lowers costs and power consumption; (iii) a modified version of Hadoop called Hadoop for Hybrid Networks (HHN), which achieves similar performance when run on hybrid Optical Circuit Switch (OCS) and Electronic Packet Switch (EPS) based datacenter networks; (iv) a novel dynamic high-speed enterprise access link design that would allow enterprises to enjoy fast transfers of large datasets without incurring the high costs of high-speed dedicated access links; (v) a storage-based Software Defined Network (SDN) architecture for supporting advance reservations of dynamic high-speed access-link circuits for improved performance relative to our initial immediate-request only circuit based design, and (vi) an application centric Energy Efficient Ethernet for 40-GE and 100-GE links to offer QoS guarantees.

The key outcomes of this project related to broader impacts criteria are as follows. This international project offered a great opportunity for students and faculty from the US and Japan to work closely together. Besides leveraging differences in applications for optical networks in the two communities, which led to interesting new networking architectures, we found the social interaction to be very educational. Research groups from both sides developed mutual respect and admiration for each others’ cultures. Next, this project offered opportunities for collaborating with Japanese industry. For example, we had a joint collaboration with NTT Labs on a  Network Function Virtualization (NFV) project called Lagopus. This project supported one PhD student, Xiaoyu (Sherry) Wang, who has published 6 conference papers and one journal paper, submitted one journal paper, and has a journal paper and conference paper under preparation. She has successfully passed the PhD Qualifying Examination and PhD Proposal Defense Examination, and will graduate in 2018. This project provided invaluable opportunities for Wang’s learning, which includes scientific research methods, Hadoop, Python, HPC usage, and Wang used NSF testbeds: GENI, Chameleon, Cloudlab, and OSG. The project also supported diversity activities run out of the University of Virginia’s Center for Diversity in Engineering (CDE). Concepts developed in this project were integrated into UG teaching. This project resulted in a total 5 journal papers, 14 conference papers, and 1 workshop paper. This high productivity was possible because this project had two collaborators in Japan and one collaborator in Univ. of Texas at Dallas.
